Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story:
I stood in the electronics aisle, my fingers tracing the edge of the Nintendo box. My son’s eyes had sparkled with hope when I promised him this gift for his birthday. As a parent, I wanted to keep my word, to see his joy, to show him that I could provide. But the price tag gnawed at me. Money was tight this month, and I knew that buying this would mean cutting corners elsewhere—maybe even skipping a donation to the church or not helping a neighbor in need as I usually did.

As a Christian, I was taught to be generous, to put others before myself, to avoid materialism. Was I teaching my son the wrong lesson by giving in to his wishes? Was I putting our family’s wants above our duty to help others? The weight of these expectations pressed on me, my heart torn between the joy of fulfilling a promise and the call to live out my faith. I stood there, wrestling with what was right, the Nintendo box growing heavier in my hands.
